title: 113_s1126
content: The "Prescribe A Book Act" establishes Pediatric Early Literacy Programs under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. It includes definitions for pediatric involvement in reading and education. The "Prescribe A Book Act" defines an eligible entity as a nonprofit organization with demonstrated effectiveness in providing peer-to-peer training to healthcare providers in literacy promotion, delivering training curriculum, offering technical assistance, and integrating research into pediatric early literacy programs. The "Prescribe A Book Act" defines an eligible entity as a nonprofit organization with demonstrated effectiveness in providing peer-to-peer training to healthcare providers in literacy promotion, delivering training curriculum, offering technical assistance, and integrating research into pediatric early literacy programs. The Act also emphasizes integrating the latest developmental and educational research into the training curriculum for healthcare providers involved in the Pediatric Early Literacy Program, which encourages parents to read aloud to their young children and provides developmentally appropriate books to children aged 6 months to 5 years during health supervision visits. The "Prescribe A Book Act" promotes literacy by providing developmentally appropriate children's books to children aged 6 months to 5 years, encouraging healthcare providers to read aloud to children in waiting areas, altering parent behavior positively, improving language skills in young children, and receiving endorsements from medical associations. The Secretary is authorized to award grants to eligible entities for Pediatric Early Literacy Programs. Eligible entities must submit an application and provide matching funds equal to at least 50% of the grant received. Grant funds must be used as specified. An eligible entity receiving a grant for Pediatric Early Literacy Programs must enter into contracts with private nonprofit organizations or public agencies based on specific criteria. Contractors must prioritize serving at-risk children, particularly those from low-income families in high-poverty areas. The entity must provide training and technical assistance to contractors and include terms determined by the Secretary for program effectiveness. Children eligible for assistance under the Pediatric Early Literacy Programs include those without adequate medical insurance, enrolled in Medicaid or CHIP programs, living in rural areas, migrant children, and those with limited access to libraries. The Secretary must ensure that eligible entities have arrangements with book publishers or distributors to obtain books at favorable discounts before making payments under the program. Eligible entities must report annually on program effectiveness. A conforming amendment is made to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. Subpart 22 outlines pediatric early literacy programs with sections on definitions, program authorization, applications, matching requirements, use of grant funds, restrictions on payments, and reporting requirements. Eligible entities must have arrangements with book publishers for discounts and report annually on program effectiveness. A conforming amendment is made to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act.
